story: Blue Cross calls for ban on using pugs and French bulldogs appearing in advertsThe Blue Cross #EndTheTrend campaign asks brands to pledge to phase out the use of brachycephalic breeds in marketing material by One of the mock advertisements that Blue Cross are placing in  London train stations Image: Blue CrossByBethan ShufflebothamNiche Writer:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA leading animal charity is calling for brands and businesses to stop using pugs and French bulldogs in their advertisements to help protect animals. It comes as flat-faced dogs continue to gain popularity, with The Kennel Club reporting a , per cent rise in the number of Frenchies registered in the last  years. As of , brachycephalic breeds account for one fth of the nation’s dog population, but owners often don’t realise that their pets could be in pain. A survey from the Royal Veterinary College revealed that  per cent of short-nosed dog owners couldn’t recognise the signs that their brachycephalic dog was struggling to breathe.  Blue Cross has launched a series of mock adverts around London calling on British brands to stop using these animals in their ad campaigns, in a bid to prevent a welfare crisis using the hashtag #endthetrend. Brachycephalic describes any dog whose muzzle looks like it has been flattened or squashed inwards. Their bottom jaw is often disproportionately longer than their upper jaw, and the dog may look as though their lower jaw sticks out. Some of the breeds that are considered as ‘brachy’ include pugs, French bulldogs and Boston terriers - with Persian cats and Lionhead rabbits also affected. And as a result of them being used to promote products that are often completely unrelated to the dogs, they’ve been given a fashionable status, and are often popular with celebrities.Fetch. Chase. Eat. Sleep. Repeat. is a new podcast from TeamDogs which takes a sideways look at what itaposs REALLY like bringing puppies into your le.Every week hosts Hannah Jones and Karen Price will be joined by celebrity dog owners like Strictly Come Dancingaposs Shirley Ballas and Coronation Street actress Samia Longchambon to chew over the adventures - and misadventures! - of puppy parenting. There will be a new episode every Tuesday and you can download it from wherever you get your podcasts from.The dog pod is brought to you by Pooch and Mutt, who are pack leaders when it comes to healthy pet food for the body and mind. Pooch and Mutt - which offers vet-recommended, naturally hypoallergenic recipes - is offering podcast listeners  per cent off on their website. To claim this discount, simply enter the code PODCAST at checkout. Terms and conditions apply. Famous faces who love their Frenchies include Lady Gaga - whose were stolen earlier this year - as well as Dwayne Johnson, Reece Witherspoon and Hugh Jackman, whilst the likes of Nicola Roberts, Paris Hilton and Kelly Osbourne have favoured pugs. But Blue Cross - who have been helping sick, injured, abandoned and homeless pets since  - say that the obsession with these animals has caused a welfare crisis, having treated over , brachy pets in the last two years.Common procedures that the charity perform on these animals include: Brachycephalic Obstructive Airway SyndromeSurgery – which they say is ‘a complicated and stressful surgery for any pet to have to undergo’, but vital to widen their nasal passages and shorten their soft palate to improve their ability to breathe. Enucleation and eyelid surgery – surgery to repair or remove their eyes and mody their eyelids due to high rates of disease. Emergency Caesarean section - because many cannot give birth to litters naturally and need medical intervention. Blue Cross explained that these health problems have stemmed from a vicious cycle of over-breeding to meet the demand for these flat-faced, four-legged friends, many of which now no longer even resemble their healthy ancestors that came just a century before them. A spokesperson for the charity added: “This has led to these breeds being seen as the latest ‘must have’ and an increase in impulse buying – often leading to pets being sold on or given up when their owners realise they cannot cope or afford vital vet bills for treatment associated with their breed. It has also led to a huge rise in the cost of puppies, particularly during the pandemic, which has sadly meant a huge rise in dog theft across the UK – with research showing that these breeds are often specically targeted.” The new End The Trend campaign asks brands to pledge to phase out the use of these pets in brand materials by the end of .  The mock advertisements have been placed in  high-profile train stations in London, including Charing Cross, London Bridge, St Pancras, Victoria and Waterloo.As part of the campaign, the charity has launched a petition which members of the public can sign to urge their favourite brands to commit to this pledge. The petition can be found here:www.bluecross.org.uk endthetrendBlue Cross vet, Caroline Reay, added: “Brachycephalic pets, like Frenchies and pugs, have soared in popularity in recent years. With their compelling big eyes and baby-like faces, our obsession with their appearance has created an animal welfare crisis. “As these breeds grow in popularity, there is a rise in parallel of unscrupulous breeders looking to cash in on a trend. Our veterinary hospital teams are treating more and more very unwell pets who are experiencing health complications caused by breeding for a characteristic ‘flat face’. “Frenchies, Pugs and Persians have become the poster pets for advertising, no matter the product, and behind those cute faces can lie horrying health problems. We call on companies to find other ways to promote their wares and help us #EndTheTrend.” Comment MORE ON TeamDogsBlue CrossRoyal Veterinary CollegeAnimals" data-immediate"data-immediate"Calling all dog lovers!to TeamDogs for your weekly dose of dog news, pictures and stories.Invalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. title: dad begs paramedics keep him
story: Dad begs paramedics to keep him alive for unborn son after being stabbed inch from heartBrave James Harrison, , was stabbed after he stepped in to break up a -man fight in his hometown of Pudsey, West Yorkshire, after England’s - draw with Scotland in the Euros on June , when he was stabbed in the backJames Harrison from Pudsey, Leeds, pictured with his partner Emily Hough and their son Lukas Image: Leeds Live MEN MediaByJoe PagnelliKate Buck:,  Oct | comments A dad who survived being stabbed just an inch from his heart said he begged paramedics to keep him alive in the hope of meeting his unborn son.Brave James Harrison, , was stabbed after he stepped in to break up a -man fight in his hometown of Pudsey, near Leeds, after England’s - draw with Scotland in the Euros on June .But it was when he felt a pain in his back that he realised someone had plunged a kne into it, reports Leeds Live. He said that in that moment he felt calm but couldn’t stop thinking about his partner Emily Hough, , who was -weeks pregnant. He was rushed to Leeds General Infirmary by ambulance where he recalled telling the paramedics: “I’m going to be a dad. Just don’t let me die, I have to meet my son.” Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Surgeons at the hospital operated for two hours and successfully removed his spleen which had been sliced through by the blade and caused him to bleed internally - and he lost more than four pints of blood. Scans later revealed that had the kne pierced just an inch higher he would have been stabbed through the heart - and likely would have died at the scene. But joyous James said it was the ‘greatest feeling in the world’ when he held his first-born son Lukas James on Aug  - just weeks after the attack which left him hospitalised. Little Lukas was born at .pm at the same hospital where James was treated, and weighed lbs oz. James, from Pudsey, said: “All I was thinking about was surviving for my family, and for my son.  “I need to get through this for Lukas. I need to survive for him. “I didn’t want my son to have a tragic story and never meet his dad. “When I finally got the chance to hold him it just felt incredible - it was everything that I thought it would be. “It was the greatest feeling in the world. After the absolute hell that we endured. “To go from nearly dying and not being able to experience that, it’s made it ten times more special. “We even forgot about all about it, the only thing that mattered was Lucas and our little family.” James said when he found out his partner of nearly two years Emily was pregnant he was overjoyed as he couldn’t wait to be a father and start his own family. But on that fateful afternoon, he said he was terried he would never see the day.  James, a telecommunications engineer, said: “I’ve been waiting all of my le to have a family and it felt like it was going to be taken from me. “I knew I had to be strong for my little boy and for Emily. I kept talking to myself and reassuring myself.” James said was driving home from the match when he saw the brawl break out near the bus stop in Pudsey. He spotted a mate and wanted to drag him out of the situation, and while looking away to check on his friend he was stabbed in the lower back from behind. The kne ruptured his diaphragm and left him unable to breathe. James added: “I closed my eyes and looked up to the sky and just said no way, I looked at my hands and they were bloodied and I knew someone had stabbed me.”  Following surgery, James had to learn how to walk again and has been told he will need to be on antibiotics for the rest of his le. But the proud dad-of-one said he feels ‘lucky’ as he was able to survive the attack and meet his son. He said: “I woke up in a high dependency unit, and when I looked down I had a massive bandage. “I felt like I had been hit by a bus. My body’s never been through so much trauma, there was the stabbing, the bruises, then the surgery. “The biggest shock was learning to walk again, as I’d been in bed for five days and when I did physio I couldn’t even stand. “I saw the MRI scans a few weeks later, and it was an inch away from my heart and I would have been dead before the ambulance even got to me. “As bad as it was, I was so lucky. “I have to take antibiotics for the rest of my le but I can still live a healthy le with my family.” James is now urging young people to stop carrying weapons and hopes to campaign in schools to raise awareness. He said: “I want to start campaigning in schools to educate children about kne crimes, my main message is to put the kne down.” Comment MORE ON Crime" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. story: Family with boy, , kicked off Heathrow plane because child wouldn’t wear face maskAngela Artis, , who was travelling back to Charlotte, in the US, claims her family were removed from an American Airlines flight that was connecting at Heathrow Airport as her son wouldnt keep a face mask onAngela Artis, , was travelling back to Charlotte, in the US, with husband Darien and son Mason Image: instagram so_angieByTim Hanlon:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA mum has claimed her family were kicked off an American Airlines flight after her two-year-old son wouldn’t keep his face mask on. Angela Artis, , was travelling back to Charlotte, in the US, with husband Darien and son Mason when they were forced off the plane at Heathrow where they were making a connection. Their holiday to Santorini, in Greece, where the couple were renewing their wedding vows, turned sour on thevia Heathrow. After being removed from the American Airlines flight  last Sunday, the airline provided overnight accommodation and rebooked the Artis family onto the following day’s flight. Mrs Artis claimed it was impossible to keep a mask on a two-year-old and that there was a baby near them that wasn’t forced to wear a face covering.  She said having got on board the plane initially everything was fine with the flight crew and her son was even given a lollipop. It turned sour, she claimed, when another flight attendant came over.She told the: “But about  minutes before the flight was due to take off another attendant came over and pointed a finger at my baby. She said aposhe needs to put a mask on or he’s got to go” in a very rude way.Mrs Artis said that her heart dropped as she had no idea it was a strict policy because she claimed that she had been able to travel before without him wearing a mask. Mrs Artis added that other flight crew in the past have accepted it is not feasible to keep the mask on a two-year-old “for more than five minutes”. She said: We had tried to put it on him for the first few minutes but he just couldn’t keep it on, it’s dficult for a baby to even physically breathe with a mask on. She said that the plane then taxied back to the terminal and the family was forced to get off the plan with an announcement that it was due to a child not wearing a mask. US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention and the Transportation Security Administration directives mean that American Airlines requires passengers aged two and older to wear face coverings at all times while indoors at airports and onboard. In a statement, the airline said: On Oct. , American Airlines flight  ed to the gate prior to departure from London Heathrow to deplane a party failing to comply with the face mask requirement. After agreeing to comply with the face mask requirement, all iniduals were rebooked for travel on the next flight to Charlotte the following day. We are reviewing this incident and a member of our team has reached out to the customers to learn more about what took place. The Mirror has contacted American Airlines for further comment. story: Girl born without bones in her legs takes her first steps after amputationPosie-Aurora Sadler-Smith, now one, was diagnosed with limb problems during her -week-scan, but medics didnt know she had fibular hemimelia until she was born.The tot has defied all expectations Image: Jodie Weeder   SWNSByRosaleen FentonAudience WriterKate Pounds:,  Oct | commentsItaposs always a special moment watching your child take their first steps - but for one couple, it was extra emotional. Their daughter Posie-Aurora Sadler-Smith, one, recently took her first steps - on her new prosthetic limbs after having an amputation. The tot was diagnosed with fibular hemimelia upon birth. The disability - where part or all of the fibula is missing - usually only impacts one leg, but Posie was missing nearly all the bones from both her lower limbs. But Posie defied the odds and learnt to crawl, using all her upper body strength to toddle around, and even boost herself on the sofa for a cuddle with pooch Seuss.Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here Her parents faced the agonising decision on whether to amputate her limbs - in order to give her a chance at walking upright. And just after her first birthday, Posie had her left leg amputated at the ankle and was later fitted with prosthetic limbs - in her favourite shade of pink, naturally. She left her parents in floods of tears after taking her first tentative tiny steps, with her dadaposs support, later that day. Parents Jodie Weeder, , and partner Dominic Sadler-Smith, , admit they miss her perfect little toes but are in awe of their daughteraposs strength.  Jodie from Sudbury, Suffolk, said: When they strapped them on at the fitting it was like she suddenly wasnapost a baby anymore. She went suddenly from this little dinky girl to such a tall toddler. We never thought we would see her stand up. It was amazing. Prosthetics take a lot of getting used to, but It was amazing to see her stand up for the first time. She canapost stand on her own with them yet because the right one needs to be altered, so we have to hold her or she holds the furniture. Sheaposs incredible. Her upper body strength is amazing - sheaposs like a little Hulk. She fallsshe lets go, but she wonapost give up. She just gets up again. Sheaposll just try and try. Jodie, who has a cleaning business, and businessman Dominic, didnapost know whether their little girl would ever walk when they found she had a chromosomal condition at  weeks pregnant. We could have had a termination, but we werenapost giving up on her Jodie said. We just focussed on getting her here and thought: aposweaposll face whatever we faceapos. At birth, she was diagnosed with fibular hemimelia. She had no right knee or bones below it, and no left ankle with only one misshaped bone in that leg. Around one-in-fty-thousand little ones have the bone condition, but itaposs much rarer for both legs to be affected.She had to wear a brace to reposition her hips for three months. Determined Posie developed a speedy crawl at six months, and had her left foot amputated on July . Her right one remains but is shorter and missing toes. Emotional parents Jodie and Dominic watched as their only child stood for the first time when she got her first prosthetic legs on September . Her right knee is so unstable she canapost stand on her own yet, so doctors will help the family decide whether it would help Posie to amputate the right leg at her knee in October, to help her prosthetics fit better. Jodie said: Prosthetics take a lot of adjustment and getting used to: you donapost just pop them on for the first time and walk. As long as youaposve got the right support around you and people who love you are backing you you can do anything. There will always be hurdles out there in anyoneaposs le: youaposve just got to overcome them. story: It’s both exciting and soothing - the wild new hobby one woman swears byAs KFC launches its limited edition Zinger Popcorn Bucket, we celebrate the thrill of trying something newWould you try lake swimming AdvertorialByEimear OHagan:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct If we’ve learnt anything over the past year and a half, it’s that you never know what’s around the corner, so itaposs important to seize opportunities, push ourselves out of our comfort zone and live for the moment. KFC is doing just that by encouraging people to spice things up to mark the launch of its tasty new Zinger Popcorn Bucket - available for a limited time only. So to join in the fun, weaposre championing people who have challenged themselves to try new things, including Jenny Holden who has ed head first into wild swimming. The forty-seven-year-old mum of ten-year-old twins from Lichfield, Staffordshire, explains that she was in search of a new challenge, and one that would bring some excitement to her le.  ‘With my children a bit older, and less dependent on me, I found myself with a little bit more time for myself, and I wanted to use it doing something fun,’ says Jenny who runs her own PR company Chorus Communications. ‘Especially post lockdowns, with so much time spent at home, being sedentary and growing bored of my normal activities, I was craving a new hobby, and one that would really exhilarate me.’ A friend suggested Jenny try wild swimming at a quarry near her home and Jenny decided to give it a go, albeit with some nerves. ‘I’m a keen swimmer but the idea of swimming in that sort of environment was completely new to me. Also, wouldn’t it be freezing  I was intrigued enough to give it a go though, and took my first dip in August with one of my sons. ‘Plunging into the water, my first thought was – wow it’s cold! But actually, once you become acclimatised to the water temperature it feels wonderful. That first swim was really memorable, I came out of the water feeling revived and invigorated, and I knew I was a convert.’ Jenny persuaded three friends to form a wild swim gang with her and since August they have met weekly for a dip. ‘I don’t wear a wetsuit, it’s too much faff getting in and out of one, just a swimsuit and now I look forward to my swim all week. ‘Front crawling through open water, surrounded by the sounds and sights nature, it’s so amazing and it washes away the stresses of the week. It’s nothing like swimming in a pool, it’s both exciting and soothing, brilliant for body and mind. ‘It’s definitely going to get a bit nippier as we go into winter but I’m ready for the challenge!’ So in the spirit of taking the plunge and trying something new, e into a Zinger Popcorn Bucket soon - it is only around for a limited period, available until November .Download the app, head in store or order online. story: Job advert for preschool worker praised for its hilariously honest requirementsJordan Jackson, the owner of Ladybridge Preschool in Bolton, posted a job advert telling candidates they would need to be fine leaving work each day "with unknown substances on your clothing" with colleagues Emma Taylorand Sarah McMyler" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _PAY-Kennedy-News-and-Media.jpg" width"" "" Preschool owner Jordan Jacksonwith colleagues Emma Taylorand Sarah McMyler Image: Kennedy News and MediaByLuke MatthewsSenior Audience Writer:,  Oct | commentsA preschool has been praised for its ultra honest job advert setting out the daily reality of working with small children - before adding: It really is all worth it. Other requirements for the job, which involves looking after children aged two to five, includes having eyes in the back of your head and offering big, warm hugs whenever required. Itaposs inspired people to apply and Iaposd loveother nurseries would advertise in the same way. I hope it inspires them. Weaposve had so many applicants and itaposs worked. story: Exclusive: Lee Rigbys mum buys first respite caravan for grieving military familiesEXCLUSIVE: Lyn Rigby has bought a caravan in Aberystwyth, West Wales, as part of the Lee Rigby Foundation which she set up in honour of her son Lee, who was murdered by terrorists in Lyn Rigby has set up the Lee Rigby Foundation in her sons memory Image: ©Billy GrfithsByRosie Dunn:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Murdered soldier Lee Rigby ’s mum has bought the first respite caravan for the charity she launched in her son’s name. Lyn Rigby vowed to look after bereaved military families like hers after grief nearly destroyed her.She set up the Lee Rigby Foundation and was overjoyed last week to get the keys to the idyllic seaside retreat in Aberystwyth, West Wales. She said: “It’s been a long, hard slog and to be honest, when the pandemic hit, I thought it was game over. But here we are, and we have finally done it! It’s nothing short of a miracle and it’s all down to the incredible generosity of people in this country who never gave up on us. Lyn set up the foundation to honour Lee, from Middleton, Greater Manchester, and make sure those suffering from loss had somewhere to turn in their bleakest moments.Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter  She said: “When I lost Lee, I had nowhere to turn so as I learned to live with my grief, I vowed to change that and provide respite for people like me who have lost loved ones. “The caravan offers families a chance to regroup and build strength and hope.” Mum of five Lyn, who runs the charity with her devoted husband Ian, wants caravans all around the British Isles. But her immediate focus is preparing Lee Rigby Retreat ready for spring next year. She said: “People have been so kind and generous. Not only have they dug deep to raise money for us through charity events, but they are also donating goods and services to do the caravan up so it’s the loveliest it can be.  “Now we have hope and a focus for the future – Lee would be so very proud.” Lyn has faced several tough years trying to establish the charity after Fusilier Lee, , was murdered by extremists in Woolwich, South East London, in . She set up Lee Rigby House in Staffordshire in  but had to leave when the owner’s circumstances changed. She came up with caravan plan but then the pandemic hit. She said: “I didn’t think we would make it through, but I am so happy that we did.” Comment MORE ON Lee Rigby" data-immediate"data-immediate"Get email updates with the days biggest storiesInvalid EmailSomething went wrong, please try again later.We use your sign-up to provide content in ways youve consented to and to improve our understanding of you. She’s sailing close to the wind, but will they say anything [the royals], no they won’t, Mr Jobson told The Mirror. The fact is they knew this was what she was going to be doing. I waited tables, babysat, and piecemealed jobs together to cover odds and ends.  I worked all my le and saved when and where I could—but even that was a luxury - because usually it was about making ends meet and having enough to pay my rent and put gas in my car. “I expect many of your constituents have their own version of that story, she continued, before attacking the US economic system. “Many of our economic systems are past their expiration date, and as you well know, too many Americans are forced to shortchange themselves when it comes to what matters to them, she added. Mum-of-two Meghan then acknowledged she does not now struggle the same way other parents who are not offered paid leave do.  She added: “In June, my husband and I welcomed our second child. While the move created some backlash from the states, Mr Jobson stressed that Meghanaposs US citizenship gives her every right to lobby the officials she votes to elect. Whilst Harry and Meghan no longer use their royal titles, they were not officially stripped of them by the Queen. However, Prince Harry did lose three honorary military titles in a review of their exit agreement in February . title: mum left battered after colliding
story: Mum left battered after colliding with taxi and landing on windscreen following hen doKylie Considine was out celebrating for a hen do of one of her mum’s friends when the night went awry and she collided with a taxi with her sister Tiegan" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _JS.jpg" width"" "" Kylie Considinewith her sister Tiegan Image: Staffs Live MEN MEDIAByGeorge Bunn:,  Oct | commentsA mum-of-five has been left covered in cuts and bruises after colliding with a taxi during a night out for a friend’s hen’s do. Kylie Considine, from Midway, near Derbyshire, was out celebrating for a hen do of one of her mum’s friends when the night went awry. The -year-old had been on her way home after the night out in Burton last weekend, when she asked to stop at a cashpoint to pay the fare for her taxi. She crossed the road to get the money out, but when running back across the road to jump into the taxi and finish her journey home, she collided with another cab. The side of her body collided with the car and she spun up into the air before coming down hard on the windscreen.  Ms Considine, a former carer who is now a full-time mum, said she had “not been out for years as [she usually is] caring for the kids”.The last bar we went to was the Locomotive. I had one drink there and we left there at about pm,” she told Staffordshire Live. “Me and my sister Teigan rang for a taxi at around .pm. I remember getting into the taxi just after that and thataposs it.” Ms Considine said she came to around an hour after the brutal collision to find herself lying on the road with the police and ambulance team looking over her. Luckily there were no broken bones, but I was covered in scrapes and bruises,” she said. “One of my thumbnails had come off, as well as my toenails. The side of my body was covered in cuts. I turned my head and saw the taxi. The side of my body had hit the car and Iaposd spun up into the air, coming down on the windscreen.” She spent a night in the hospital at Nottingham and was discharged early the next day. Ms Considine doesn’t think what happened to her has sunk in yet, claiming the “whole thing doesn’t feel real”. “I was absolutely in agony through the whole weekend. I usually donapost like to just sit around, but I havenapost left the house this week. I couldnapost lt my arms properly at the weekend. My eldest son is still in shock and my daughter ran out and cried aposmummyaposs poorlyapos and mummyaposs hurtapos. I was just heartbroken. Iaposve lost a few minutes of my le as my mind is completely blank. Everything I know about what happened has been told to me. The doctor said that was because of the concussion.” The mum said the experience was “upsetting”, leaving her feeling vulnerable and unsafe. While she was now able to get herself out of bed, she said she wasn’t able to do much . A spokesperson from Derbyshire Constabulary said: We were called just after .pm on Friday October  to reports of a collision involving a car and a pedestrian on High Street at Newhall. The pedestrian, a woman aged in her s, was taken to hospital by ambulance for her injuries to be checked. It is not thought they were serious,” the spokesperson said. Police were now appealing for information from anyone who may have witnessed the collision or have information which could help with enquiries. You also need to shop around for a good deal look for the best places to buy your paint and materials.  The most important things are planning and being creative. I think a lot of it is confidence as well. A lot of the stuff I do is to try and encourage people to give things a go. story: New map reveals Delta Plus iant hotspots across England as cases continue to riseA newly published map shows where the Delta Plus iant hotspots are across the country as cases and deaths continue to rise but scientists warn the new iant is "unlikely to change the picture"The new AY., Delta Plus iant is popping up across the country Image: Reach PLCByKieren Williams:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA new map has revealed where the Delta Plus iant hotspots are across England, as cases continue to rise.The AY.., or Delta Plus iant, has caused alarm in the past couple of days but in a press conference yesterday health secretary Sajid Javid told the public there was no evidence the mutation was more dangerous.This new strain of the virus was first discovered in July . shower is a spectacle like no other, giving skygazers a chance to see pieces from the famous Halleyaposs Commet. The comet only passes earth every  or  years, but luckily itaposs possible to see the debris in the form of shooting stars every October.Luckily, the  Orionid meteor shower will be visible across the whole globe – including the UK. story: Pub-goer reports BBC star James Naughtie to police after spotting him drink drivingGordon Duncan spoke of how he witnessed James Naughtie “gulp down” the big glass of wine while chatting away to someone in the bar in Edinburgh, Scotland, before jumping into his car to drive homeJames Naughtie has been fined a total of £ and banned from driving for  months Image: PAByIona Young:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA pub-goer has shared how he reported a BBC radio presenter to police for drink driving. James Naughtie, , was spotted by Gordon Duncan downing a “large Chardonnay” at Bennet’s bar, in the Edinburgh suburb of Morningside in Scotland, before leaving to drive home. Gordon, who was previously a regular at the bar, was shocked when he noticed the presenter getting into his car, and reported the series of events to police. Gordon hasn’t felt comfortable going back to the pub he spent  years as a regular since the incident, he said.Speaking to Edinburgh Live, Gordon spoke of how he witnessed Naughtie “gulp down” the big glass of wine while chatting away to someone in the bar.“On this I decided to go outside and pretend I was on a call in the Bennets garden,” he said.  “The guy came out  minutes later and got into his new car and drove off. I took a picture of his car and noted the number plate too. “I then called police immediately.” Gordon explained that he doesn’t believe in drink drivers”. “Itaposs disgusting in this day and age where we have one of the best public services. People who drink drive should be sent to prison,” he said. “I was never afraid to report him, I hate drink drivers I would report him again or someone doing same thing.  Naughtie, , was spotted getting into his car after he had stopped off for a glass of wine at Bennets Bar in Morningside, Edinburgh. The award-winning journalist was traced to his nearby capital home by police officers and admitted he had been driving his vehicle that afternoon in October . He was asked was to provide a roadside breath test and was found to have mg of alcohol in ml of breath. The legal limit is just mg of alcohol. The retired Radio  news anchor appeared in the dock at Edinburgh Sherf Court under his full name of Alexander James Naughtie in June where he pleaded guilty to driving while over the limit. Prosecutor Ross Price said: “Around pm in the afternoon the accused left Bennet’s Bar and a member of staff saw him getting into his vehicle and called police. “Officers made enquiries and attended at the accused’s home address at .pm and breathalysed him. “He confirmed he was the driver [of the vehicle] that afternoon.” Solicitor Sean Flanagan, defending, said his client had been driving to his Edinburgh home and decided to stop off at the public house “for one glass of wine”. The lawyer added Naughtie, whose address was given as Blackthorn Avenue, London, had only driven “a relatively short distance” from the bar to his home and had cooperated fully with police. Sherf Peter McCormack fined the motorist a total of £ and banned him from driving for  months. The sherf said Naughtie would be allowed to take part in a drink drive rehabilitation schemehe chooses which,passed successfully, would see his road ban reduced by three months. Naughtie pleaded guilty to driving a vehicle with mg of alcohol in ml of breath at Maxwell Street, Morningside Road and Cluny Gardens, all Edinburgh, on October , . she greeted them in a reception at Windsor Castle.Pinned to her beautul turquoise suit was an even more dazzling diamond brooch thought to be made from the largest rough diamond ever discovered.And year.The brooch, called the Cullinan V brooch, comes from the huge Cullinan diamond, which was discovered in South Africa in  - measuring in at , carats. It was presented to Edward VII in  and part of it was used to create the stunning .-carat heart-shaped diamond at the centre of a platinum brooch for Queen Mary. The -year-old monarch was feeling “a little tired” on Tuesday evening before royal doctors were called to her living quarters at Windsor Castle, it is understood. Upon waking on Wednesday morning, ahead of a planned departure from her Berkshire home at midday to travel to Belfast, the steely Queen was said to be “showing slight signs of a seasonal cold”. Her Majesty, who has had a jam-packed schedule of engagements since ing from her summer break at Balmoral, took a Covid test which confirmed she was not suffering from coronavirus.But palace medics advised her to take a period of “immediate rest” for the next few days. The nation’s longest-reigning monarch is resting at Windsor Castle but will still receive her ministerial red boxes which she will attend to. title: ricky gervais petition stop animal
story: Ricky Gervais petition to stop animal testing just k away from being debated in ParliamentThe petition calls to include lab animals in the Animal Welfare ActRicky Gervais with Scarlett the beagle Image: K MagazineByCatherine Swan:,  Oct | commentsMore than , people have signed a petition calling for a change in the law which will include laboratory animals in the Animal Welfare Act.The petitionjust needs a few more thousand signatures to hit ,, at which point it will be considered for debate in Parliament.The Animal Welfare Act currently prevents “unnecessary suffering” to protected animals, which includes any animal looked after by humans as well as all wild animals. However, the Act doesn’t apply to animals used for “scientic or educational purposes”. Animals are currently used to test things like the development of medicine and vaccines, studying how animal and human bodies work, and to test chemicals for their possible impact on human health or the environment. According to the RSPCA, it’s estimated that over  million animals are used for testing across the world every year.  The petition page reads: “A recent exposé showed harrowing footage of the factory farming of laboratory dogs in the UK. Experiments on such dogs, and other animals, are today widely reported to be entirely failing the search for human treatments and cures. “Current science from multiple fields proves that animal-based research and testing is not viable. The Government should therefore change the law to include laboratory animals under the protection of the Animal Welfare Act, to prevent their unnecessary suffering.” The campaign was set up by Ricky Gervais and actor Peter Egan, along with ‘Beagle Ambassador” Scarlett, a dog who was rescued from a lab after being tested on for two years. Beagles are a breed commonly chosen for animal testing due to their docile nature. The petition was launched after footage was released showing the treatment of dogs at an animal testing laboratory. In the video, the dogs can be heard whimpering as they are loaded onto a lorry in small cages. The footage then goes on to show a dog being fed an unknown substance through a tube, and bins labelled ‘dogs’ being wheeled out of the laboratory.  “It’s heartbreaking to hear these puppies crying out for mercy and help,” comedian Ricky said of the footage. “We need an immediate ban on this shocking animal cruelty.” The Government previously responded to the petition in August this year, saying: “The use of animals in scientic research remains a vital tool in improving our understanding of how biological systems work both in health and disease.” They also argued that the AnimalsAct , which means that anyone who wants to use animals for testing purposes must be licensed and get authorisation from the Home Office, is enough to protect affected animals.But campaigners are calling on the Government to carry out apublic scientic hearingto ban experiments on animals. Anopen letterby For Le On Earth, a campaign fighting against animal testing, which calls for the hearing to take place was signed by several famous supporters including Chris Packham, Paul O’Grady, and Dr Jane Goodall. So far, over  MPs have supported the motion. story: All secondary school pupils and staff in entire county told to wear masks againSecondary school pupils and staff in Suffolk are going to be asked to wear face masks again as Covid cases continue to rise, with hospitalisations up in all regions of England" content"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES n _Masks-Compulsory-For-Secondary-School-Students-In-Scotland.jpg" width"" "" Secondary school pupils and staff in Suffolk are going to be asked to wear face masks again Image: Getty ImagesByKieren Williams:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsSecondary school staff and pupils in Suffolk are going to be asked to wear face masks again as Covid cases continue to rise. Stuart Keeble, Suffolk County Councilaposs director of public health, told BBC Radio aposs Today programme that the virus is really working its way through that younger population at the moment. For me now it is also about trying to keep children in school. We have had around , pupils test positive in the last  days. If we can keep transmission rates down, we can also keep more pupils in school as well while the vaccine is being run out for  to -year-olds. He added that there was the risk the virus could spread through school children to the older population, their parents and grandparents.  Mr Keeble added: We have started to see that. We have started to see an increase over the last few weeks in that parent age group of those in secondary school. He also said they are now also increase in cases in over-s and this is a concern given, there are more vulnerable people in those age groups. This comes amidst growing concerns as cases and hospitalisations continue to rise in the UK as the country heads towards winter. Covid hospitalisations are up in every region of England and Wales, with the South East seeing the most dramatic increase of a % rise in hospitalisations in one week.  With , new covid cases yesterday, October , there has been growing calls for a ‘Plan B’ to deal with the issue.However, in a press conference yesterday health secretary Sajid Javid pushed back against the need for a ‘Plan B’ saying it was not time for it yet.He said that the NHS was not yet under “unsustainable” pressure and called on Brits to show their “Blitz spirit” and get their Covid booster jab.. Despite the NHS Confederation calling for a new approach, Javid said: I’ve got a lot of time for the NHS Confederation… they do a lot of good work.  On this particular question we don’t believe the pressures currently faced by the NHS are unsustainable. Donapost get me wrong, there are huge pressures, especially in AE, in primary care for example as well. But at this point we donapost believe they are unsustainable. He did call upon people to continue to wear face masks in enclosed spaces, but stopped short of making it mandatory. Javid warned that restrictions would “of course” Brits did not wear masks or get their booster jabs when able to. to Archie and Lilibet. Meghan addressed the letter to Senate Leader Chuck Schumer and Speaker of the House of Representatives Nancy Pelosi, acknowledging she is not an elected official or politician, but wanted to speak as a mom on the issue.She also wrote about the sacrices working parents have to make not just in pursuit of the American Dream, but simply the dream of stability. story: Man arrested after young woman injected with needle in nightclubThe victim was rushed to AE and spent the night in hospital after the terrying incident, which happened last Tuesday in Nottingham. A man has been arrestedEllie SImpson, whose sister was targeted in a Nottingham nightclubByCallum Parke:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct A man has been arrested days after a young woman was allegedly injected with a needle in a nightclub. The victim was rushed to AE and spent the night in hospital after the terrying incident, which allegedly happened last Tuesday in Nottingham. Ellie Simpson, the womanaposs sister, said her sibling was with friends in Stealth nightclub when she felt a pinching or scratching sensation on the back of her arm. She began to feel ill, and was taken to AE, where she spent the night on a drip.Ellie told Derbyshire Live that her sister, who studies in Nottingham but is from Derby, has been left seriously shaken by the experience. She said: Sheaposs OK now, but sheaposs still really shaken up and afraid to go out. She went out for a night out and had only had a couple of drinks, so had drank less than she would normally. They were trying to leave the club and on the way out she felt something on the back of her arm, a pinching or scratching sensation, and she canapost remember anything after that. The police took urine samples so I donapost knowthey will be able to find anything. I felt sick, because you see these things happen to other people. You never expect to have it happen to anybody that you know. And then I obviously felt angry, and you just question why, why does somebody want to do that  What were their intentions  Iaposm just thankful she was with a friend becauseshe wasnapost, what would have happened  Spiking is the act of adding alcohol or a drug to food or drink without the knowledge of the person who consumes it. Reports of spikings have been re across the country in recent weeks, with particular concern about the use of needles given the risk of infection with HIV.It is recommended by the NHS that anyone concerned about contracting HIV should use soap to clean the wound, and buy anti-HIV medication within  hours of the incident.Signs that a drink may have been tampered with include a foggy appearance, excessive bubbles, sinking ice or a change in colour. If someone has been spiked, it is recommended to tell a member of staff and to ensure someone stays with the victim, calling an ambulancetheir condition deteriorates. It is important to ensure they do not travel on their own, or drink more alcohol. But Ellie, who has herself been spiked while studying in Loughborough, says women can only do so much to protect themselves and that more should be done to create a safe environment for everyone. She said: Ever since that [Ellie being spiked], my sister has been a lot more conscious in terms of putting your hands over your drink. But when itaposs a needle, how do you stop that  You canapost. Unless you go out in a suit of armour, which weaposre not going to do. Evenyou do search people, itaposs like looking for a needle in a haystack. I personally I donapost know how youaposd go about stopping it, as metal detectors may not pick needles up as theyaposre so small. As women, we shouldnapost have to go out on a night out, thinking have I got my bag, have I got my keys, then thinking, am I safe to go out, am I going to get spiked tonight  It shouldnapost be like that. Boycotts of nightclubs across the country have been organised over the next fortnight in protest. Using the name aposGirls Nights Inapos, events are happening in Derby and Nottingham on Wednesday, October , to coincide with Wednesday nights often being busy student nights, with similar happening across the country into early November. But Ellie has said that anyone, including men, are welcome and encouraged to become part of the campaign for greater awareness and protection in clubs. To other men it must seem like we are blaming them, even though we know it is not all men. I suppose in a club environment, the only sort of way I would feel safe isyou could see a manaposs hands and know where they are, but how you do that  And you shouldnapost have to do that. But weaposre keen to say itaposs not all men. Nottinghamshire police have said that a -year-old man has been arrested after receiving reports of a number of incidents in recent days. He has since been released on bail. He was arrested on suspicion of possession of class A and class B drugs and cause to administer poison or noxious thing with intent to injure, aggrieve and annoy following an incident in Lower Parliament Street on October , four days after Ellieaposs sister was spiked.A petition for greater security checks for nightclubs has also reached over , signatures, surpassing the threshold needed for the matter to be debated in Parliament. title: spiked dancers eyes rolled back
story: Spiked dancers eyes rolled back after drink is laced while she performsMum-of-one Katie Brady, , was working as a dancer at a Newcastle nightclub and says her drink was spiked while she was performing on the podium Image: Katie BradyBySophie BrownsonRyan FaheyNews Reporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA mum-of-one blacked out after being spiked while dancing at a club. Katie Brady, , says the last thing she remembered of the night was placing her drink on the podium before she danced at the nightclub in Newcastle. After that she recalls nothing of her night.Katie, from Birtley, Gateshead, told Chronicle Live : I was told afterward that I had gone to the toilets and the door staff had to carry me out and give me water.[They said that] my eyes had rolled back into my head and that later on, I had just walked away from the bar. Luckily, I was using ABC Taxis and I managed to ring a taxi and it was a driver I knew who came.  He helped me into the taxi and to my front door where he knocked to make sure my mam would wake up. Katie was  at the time and said when she ed to her home in Bensham, her mum thought she was just drunk. I had no memory at all of that night, she said. My mam took a photo and told me that she heard me being sick and then heard a bang and said I had fallen backward in the bathroom. Bar staff later confirmed sheaposd only had one drink, leaving no other explanation in her mind other than a spiking. But she had no evidence so decided not to report it to the police. She believes this was the first time she was spiked, with the second happening several years later at a dferent Newcastle venue. Her drink was tampered with while chatting with friends at the bar, she said. Katie, who was then aged , said: My friend had served me the drink as she worked in the bar and we were stood by the bar which wasnapost very busy. I had my drink on the bar and no one was beside me and thataposs the last thing I remember. When I spoke to a friend afterwards, they said that one of the staff had said to her aposyou need to go and see [Katie] she is in a bad way.apos My friend took me to the bus stop and I managed to get the bus home. My partner said that when I got home I was throwing up black vomit and I passed out on the sofa. The bar checked for CCTV evidence but the way she was standing meant they could not see whether someone was looming behind her. Mum-of-one Katie says she was left shaken after the two incidents - and is now less confident about going out on the town. I have been really lucky... it could have been completely dferent, she said. It did scare me and I didnapost go out for a long time afterward. It is scary to think what could have happened. In an effort to look out for drinkers, three city centre venues have increased security and CCTV cameras as well creating safe spaces for vulnerable people to seek help. The Market Shaker, The Dog and Parrott and Pumphreys Newcastle are the venues taking action, with measures including offering lids for drinks and kits to test whether beverages have been spiked. Katie said she feels reassured by such measures and felt aposrelievedapos that action was being taken. I am so happy they are doing something like this, she said. story: UK weather: Flooding hits UK as cars abandoned and mini tornado wreaks havocStorm Aurore made its way across from France last night, bringing mph winds and several centimetres of rain that hit London, Essex, Sussex and Kent particularly badly overnight Image: Stephen Huntley HVCByMilo BoydReporter:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsMotorists had to be evacuated from their cars after lashing rains caused parts of England to flood overnight. An elderly man was photographed being led from his stranded vehicle which got stuck in a foot of water in Southend, Essex. The town had already endured a miserable day of weather on Wednesday, with overwhelmed drains pumping raw sewage out onto the sea front. Across the county more than  people had called the fire service for emergency help with flood related incidents before .am. Have you been impacted by the flooding  Email webnews@mirror  In Sussex the M was shut between junction  and  following a serious crash, leaving emergency services needing to clear water and debris. Earlier on Wednesday a suspected mini tornado caused havoc in Widnes, Cheshire with garden walls, bins and ornaments flung onto the main road. Late last night residents of Ferring in West Sussex took to social media to claim they have also been struck by a tornado. One person said: I’m in Ferring, I was in my daughter’s room at the time and we heard a bang and the windows shook and both wondered what on earth has happened.  Locals shared photos of damage to their gardens, including a smashed brick wall and toppled furniture. Four people had to be rescued from the roof of their car after it became swamped.  They were left balancing on the top of the vehicle that was stuck in four feet of fast flowing water at St Kew, Cornwall.Police were first on the scene just before .pm and then called in Cornwall Fire and Rescue Service.Crews from Wadebridge and Delabole were sent along with water rescue units from St Austell and Bude, supported by an Area manager and group manager.  Londoners complained of “terrying” journeys home on Wednesday night. One person tweeted: “The rain tonight coming back from London was the worst I’ve seen in a long time. Loads of deep flooding from Hammersmith through to the M.” Another wrote: “Terrying drive home from West London to Rochester, Medway. Torrential rain all the way with flooding and stranded vehicles along the route. Still raining...”  People across the south of the country woke up to tumultuous scenes of flooding this morning after a storm moving in from France brought with it strong winds and heavy rains. Storm Aurore was expected to dump mm of rain and blow mph winds in the worst affected areas. The Met Office issued a yellow rain warning covering most of southern England for Wednesday night and into Thursday, meaning people living there could see transport delays, flooding and power issues. The Met Office issued yellow rain warnings for the southern counties and Channel Islands until am on Thursday, but said the most severe impact of the storm would be over northern France.  It added the unsettled weather was likely to continue for the rest of the week, with showers and breezy conditions across western Scotland and some areas of central and northern England and Wales on Friday. Forecasters predict there to be more persistent rain over the weekend, with the heaviest rain expected in western Scotland, where -mm could fall in  hours. Northern Ireland, northern England and Wales, could see up to mm of rain, while southern and central areas will see light rain. story: Exclusive: Student left unable to speak after uni dad spikes her on freshers night outAnna Stephen was left to stagger home by herself after a bouncer blocked her from a nightclub in Edinburgh in an incident that has left her feeling frightened and sickenedAnna Stephen says she was spiked on a night out Image: Anna Maria Stephen InstagramByMilo BoydReporter:,  Oct A student was left unable to speak after she was spiked on a night out with her uni dad. Anna Stephen had had four drinks before reaching a club in Edinburgh with a group of boys from the year above, who were known as the freshersapos dads as part of the uniaposs buddy system. Having been drinking for several years, the now -year-old knew her limits and was fully in control all night until she got out of the taxi by the venue. Thinking sheaposd had too much to drink, the bouncer blocked Anna from going inside and told her to go and drink some water. After staggering to Tesco to get some water and slumping on the floor, the student managed to stagger home to her friendaposs house. There she lay on the floor for hours, unable to talk and vomiting relentlessly.  While Anna was physically unharmed by whoever drugged her, the experience has shaken her deeply. Sheaposs unsure who specically spiked her, leading her to completely remove herself from the friendship group. The worst things about this whole experience was that I was unable to speak for most of it and didn’t feel in control of my body at all, but I remember everything so clearly, she told The Mirror. I’ve been spiked since, a couple of years ago in Ibiza, and the experience was the same. It makes me sick because it’s so frightening and would be sosomeone was attacked in this state too. Youaposd be unable to do anything to try and stop it. Anna is one of the many people who are bravely coming forward to share their experience of being spiked, following alarming reports that nightle predators are using needles to inject drugs into victims. Tammy Kendall is another woman whose been targeted in Edinburgh clubs - not just once, but three times, in three dferent venues.  On one occasion she was out with her dad when she suddenly started feeling really unwell. The -year-old blacked out and has no memory of the night. When she awoke the next day, friends told her sheaposd been so sick and delirious, she kept saying she wanted to kill herself. On another occasion she was kicked out of a club by a bouncer who thought she was too drunk, leaving Tammy to pass out on the street outside.  During the third she was relentlessly sick. It was the worst things I have ever experienced, she recalled. I couldn’t remember where I was, the date or who I was with. I couldn’t remember how I got home, I was being violently sick and I was spewing blood.Tammy and Anna are just two of dozens of people who have shared their experiences of being spiked in Edinburgh on a single Instagram post.The alarmingof the thread, and the distressing details of many of the comments, hints at how large a problem spiking is in the UK.  Figures obtained by the BBC show that there were , reported incidents in England and Wales since . Many incidents of drink spiking go unreported because people are unaware they’ve fallen victim to it, meaning the true number is likely much higher. What to do about such a common place yet upsetting issue is dficult. In the past week calls to increase security at bars and clubs have gained traction, yet some argue searches are easy to evade and may further discriminate against the already marginalised. Calls for women to take additional preventative measures have been knocked back by those who argue it should not be the victimaposs responsibility to foil perpetrators. Anna believes that the onus to protect victims lies in numerous places. I know it’s a big ask, but the clubs and pubs also have a responsibility towards the public as per licensing to make sure they are safe, she said. I also think we as the public can do more to help. Like the amount of people who just walk past people who’re struggling or those who are too embarrassed to askthey need help. We need to start being more forward thinking as a society and not be scared to ask someonethey are okay. title: well never take back control
story: Well never take back control of Covid while out-of-touch Tories keep heads in sandDespite rising infection rates and deaths and a sluggish booster campaign, theres no change of policy on Covid and no change of attitude from the self-serving Tories, writes Paul RoutledgeVaccines minister Maggie Throup Image: Derby opinionByPaul Routledge:,  Oct | commentsTHE Government sent the Minister for Vaccines to Parliament yesterday for an update on the Covid ­crisis. Stumbling, tongue-tied Maggie Throupcould barely read out her prepared statement. Embarrassing. It doesn’t matter, because it said nothing new. The Government is paralysed in the face of mounting Covid dangers. Ms Throup droned out the official line: Stick to Plan A. No Plan B, no ­mandatory face coverings on public transport or in schools, no vaccine ­passports for crowded events, noto social distancing, no push for homeworking. Nothing, except for some gratuitous advice to behave sensibly and wait until the end of the year for a “miracle pill” that could halve Covid deaths. But the crisis is now. The Government admits infection rates are soaring towards , a day. A new, more contagious iant of Delta is circulating, hospital admissions are rising and the death toll has surged to , a week. The booster campaign is sluggish, and vaccination of  to -year-olds patchy at best. In my village of Sutton and Crosshills the infection rate has doubled to . per ,. Covid is raging through North Yorkshire schools, and our academy has , pupils. I no longer shop at my Co-op during school breaks, because they congregate in groups without masks. Admissions to our local hospital are up %, and one patient has died. The outlook is bad, but Boris Johnson, in hock to his hardline Covid Recovery Group of free-market backbench MPs, resolutely buries his head in the sand. It is not a pretty sight, especially when he talks through his backside. He claims Covid is “under control”. Hardly. He should “take back control”. He’s completely out of touch with public opinion. Our daily poll shows % of Mirror readers back reintroduction of restrictions. What will it take for him to wake up to reality  **********Expect chaos in Glasgow tomorrow when tens of thousands of foreign delegates arrive for the HotAirAthon, aka COP.Matron Nicola Sturgeon this week made vaccine passports compulsory for admission to such events. Imagine the scene on the door: “Che  You want see my arm  Habla ze jabs, but I no etiendo Glaswegian.” The biblical Tower of Babel was a marvel of mutual understanding by comparison with the next fortnight in Glasgie. **********The resting Queen, aged , has given up her daily martini. Is that all I’ve got to look forward to  Her mum was still knocking it back as a centenarian. Cocktails of gin and Dubonnet at noon, red wine with lunch and port afterwards. And champers at the “Magic Hour” of six o’clock.The Queen Mother hid bottles of gin in hatboxes when she was on royal tours. A more encouraging model, perhaps. That’swe can afford it. Grim warnings that beer will go up by p a pint, breaching the psychological £ barrier round here. It seems like only yesterday I was paying s d for a pint of Tetley’s in Normanton. But it was actually  years ago. title: worlds biggest polluters tried watering
story: Some of world’s biggest polluters tried to water down landmark UN climate reportA massive leak of documents has shown countries such as Australia and Saudi Arabia are among some trying to downplay the need to switch away from fossil fuelsLeaked documents have revealed some of the worlds biggest polluters have tried to downplay the need to switch away from fossil fuels Image: AFP via Getty ImagesByNada FarhoudEnvironment editor:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | comments Some of the world’s most polluting countries tried to water down a landmark UN climate report, according to a massive leak of documents.Major coal exporter Australia and oil-rich Saudi Arabia were among those wanting the report to downplay the need to switch away from fossil fuels.An Australian government official rejected the conclusion that coal-fired power plants must be closed – even though ending coal use is an objective of next month’s COP summit.Major beef producers Argentina and Brazil are said to have disputed claims that the world must cut its meat consumption to tackle climate change. Saudi Arabia, the worldaposs biggest oil exporter, requested that the UN scientists delete their conclusion that the focus of decarbonisation efforts in the energy systems sector needs to be on rapidly shting to zero-carbon sources and actively phasing out fossil fuels. Get all the latest news sent to your inbox.for the free Mirror newsletter Japan, which is hugely reliant on fossil fuels in its energy and transport systems, rejects a key finding in the report’s summary for policymakers detailing how coal and gas-fired power stations will, on average, need to be shut down within  and  years respectively to keep warming below .°C and  and  years to keep warming below °C. A director in Japan’s ministry of foreign affairs claims this paragraph is misleading and suggests deleting it “because the required retirements of fossil fuel power plants due to carbon budget depend on the emissions from other sectors as well as their capacity factor and the opportunities of CCS.” A senior scientist from Indiaaposs Central Institute of Mining and Fuel Research, which has strong links to the Indian government, warns coal is likely to remain the mainstay of energy production for decades because of what they describe as the tremendous challenges of providing affordable electricity. India is already the worldaposs second-biggest consumer of coal. The documents obtained by Greenpeace contain , submissions by governments, companies and other interested parties to the IPCC, the UN body compiling scientic evidence on how to tackle climate change.  Greenpeace International chief Jenner Morgan said: “This is an insight into how a small group of coal, oil and meat producing countries continue to put the profits of a few polluting industries before science and our planet’s future. The key test for world leaders is whether or not they agree to rapidly phase out fossil fuels, as the science warrants. History will not be kind to themthey fail.” The IPCC said comments from governments are central to its scientic review process but that its authors have no obligation to incorporate them into the reports. It added: “Our processes are designed to guard against lobbying – from all quarters.” It came after the Environment Agency issued over  flood warnings following heavy rain on Wednesday night and early yesterday as Storm Aurore moved in from France. news us-news hundreds-dolphins-leap-out-water-"Hundreds of dolphins spotted off Calornian coast in super podByMichael Havis:,  Oct Updated:,  Oct | commentsA apossuper podapos comprising of hundreds of dolphins have been seen springing out of the water simultaneously more than a mile wide across the water in incredible new footage. The “super pod”, comprising an estimated  dolphins, can be seen stretching off into the distance, leaping out of the water as they race a whale-watching boat. The amazing scene was captured by the crew of the Catallac, the vessel travelling alongside the dolphins, while it toured the coast off Newport Beach, Calornia, USA. Super pods, which can number more than , dolphins, form where food is plentul, but usually gather in deep water and are far rarer in shallower seas. Jessica Roame, education manager at Newport Landing Whale Watching, which operates the Catallac, said the dolphins may also have been fleeing an unseen predator. “Porpoising out of the water at a high rate of speed is the fastest mode of travel for dolphins because there is less resistance in the air than in water,” she said.  “That’s why these dolphins move in this way when theyaposre in a hurry, and when hundreds of dolphins do this together, we call this a stampede.” Jessica said it was not known exactly what causes dolphins to stampede, but it was thought they could have been evading a predator or catching up to a food source. Jessica estimated that there were some  inidual dolphins stampeding in the video. A typical pod contains anything from two to . “Every time you see a dolphin on the surface, there are normally three or four dolphins underneath the surface,” she said. “They could be related family members in their pod, or multiple pods of common dolphins coming together, and likely this is because of food.”  Patrick Webster of Monterey Bay Aquarium, approximately  miles to the north, said a super pod sighting was one of the ocean’s “magical moments”. “It is fairly rare to see them this close to shore and so readily observable by people,” he said, following a sighting in . Itaposs a very special sighting nearshore of one of the oceanaposs magical moments often hidden away from human observation. “But to the dolphins, it was probably just another Monday.” Newport Landing Whale Watching runs daily whale and wildle watching tours of the Southern Calornia coast all year round. story: Dad-to-be finds perfect baby name by ensuring it follows  strict rulesThe top baby names in  might have been revealed, but this blogger had a dferent way of decidingWould you let a mathematical algorithm decide your baby name  Image: GettyByEmily Sleight:,  Oct | comments It looks like Olivia and Oliver have bagged first place on the top baby names for , but it’s bad news for Nigels and Carols. Many have been using TV as inspiration, with the rise of names like ‘Maeve’ and ‘Otis’ from hit Netflix show Sex Education.Margot, after Margot Robbie’s appearance in The Wolf of Wall Street also saw a rise in popularity, as well as ‘Kylo’ from Star Wars’ Kylo Ren. Blogger Nick Winter found a more unconventional inspiration for his childaposs name - he used a mathematical algorithm.Yes, you can actually use mathematics to determine something like a baby name - who knew  It took a little bit of work though, and this method definitely isn’t for those with little patience. So, how did blogger Nick do it  Firstly, he downloaded the entire Social Security name database onto his computer, which had , names on it that have been used more than five times since . He then wrote his very own web app which ranked all the names according to  algorithmic ranking criteria.Maths-Whizz is a super clever virtual maths tutor which delivers interactive games, lessons and exercises for five to  year olds.To see how good it is at transforming home learning for parents, weaposve negotiated an exclusive % off price to make it £. for the first month.Seeyou like it first and sign up to a -day no-obligation free trial by you can do that here. If you want to sign up for a month at a time or even a year, you can do that here but donapost forget to use the promo code aposMATHSapos.  The  dferent ranking criterias were as follows:aposSpellabilityapos - penalises names which sound similar to other common names, since people will not know how to spell them. Pronounceability - penalises names which we think could be pronounced two dferent ways, or which have Rs in them. Timelessness - penalises anything thataposs extra old-fashioned, is extra trendy now, or was a fad name in the past. Relevancy - penalises very rare names. Rarity - penalises names that are very common. Secularity - penalises names which are clearly Biblical. Shortness - penalises names with many letters or many syllables. aposRecitabilityapos - penalises names that arenapost easy to spell aloud. aposNicklessnessapos - penalises names that have shorter nickname versions. aposNickednessapos - penalises names that are nicknames of longer names. aposChinesenessapos - penalises names that would be hard to pronounce for native Chinese speakers due to unfamiliar consonant clusters and other sound patterns. aposGenderednessapos - penalises names that are ambiguously gendered. The web app allowed him to specy which points were important to him and which points were not.In his blog, he said: “For me, this was the obvious way to do it. I quickly went through about  of the , names, liking  and hating the rest. “Chloedid about  namesand liked  of them. “We then reviewed each otheraposs, often using the phone test, where you pretend to answer the phone with your name . This left an overlap of about  names .” To make the final decision, they both put their favourite options calculated by the web app on a sticky note on the fridge and took down the ones they didnapost want until just two remained. The two winners were Hazel and Max and shortly after, Chloe gave birth to a little baby boy, so Max it was. title: harry potter inspired flat diagon
story: Harry Potter-inspired flat in Diagon Alley on sale - and it even has a hidden roomIf youre a Harry Potter fan, weve got a property that is right up your alley - Diagon Alley to be exact - a gorgeous one-bed flat in the heart of Edinburghs Grassmarket areaEdinburghs Grassmarket Image: Jam Press Warners Solicitors  EByPaige HollandShowbiz Audience Writer:,  Oct | commentsA Harry Potter-themed flat complete with a hidden room has hit the market for £,. The one-bed property, located in the heart of Edinburghaposs Grassmarket area, was previously used as a short-term holiday let for the millions of visitors who flock to Victoria Street every year – which is said to have inspired J.K. Rowling’s Diagon Alley. Located just minutes from Edinburgh’s top attractions, the flat is prime Potter real estate, neighbouring several of the cafés where the author wrote early chapters of the book franchise. Owners will also have Edinburgh Castle on their doorstep, which is claimed to have served as inspiration for Hogwarts. For more of the news you care about, straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here. The flat’s front door opens into a hallway that contains secret storage space disguised by a long mirror . The impressive sized living space and modern kitchen-diner boast plenty of natural light and some wallpaper that fans of the franchise will recognise is similar to that of the magical photos which hang in the halls of Hogwarts.  A woodland-themed bedroom, hidden behind a fantastically concealed bookcase door, helps give the feel of being in The Forbidden Forest – though thankfully thereaposs no giant spider named Aragog in sight. A compact bathroom, with a double shower and a rustic copper coin floor, gives the newly-refurbished apartment an eclectic homely feel that any Weasley would be proud of. Other features of the pad include a wizarding chest, references to Gringottaposs Bank, antique books and a Diagon Alley sign.  Despite its bustling location, the propertyaposs newly installed slimline sash and case double glazed windows with handmade shutters are sure to keep the noisy moaning myrtles or dementor-like drafts at bay. Eventually, he confessed that he had in fact been seeing someone  and she was also three months pregnant. I didnapost know what to do other than walk away. I was almost in shock, dude we had been together almost a year. Heaposd been step-daddy to my kids and all that, we were emotionally attached. story: When will the Covid- pandemic end  WHO warns its going on longer than it needs toAlthough Covid- restrictions have eased completely in the UK, the World Health Organisation has warned that the pandemic will likely drag on into  and could last even longer due to a low average of vaccination rates across the worldWHO has warned the pandemic is going on longer than it needs to Image: GettyByBenjamin LynchSEO writer:,  Oct | comments The World Health Organisationhas warned that the coronavirus pandemic will likely drag on into , due to a lack of vaccinations across the world, particularly in poorer countries.Dr Bruce Aylward, senior leader at the WHO, said: I can tell you weaposre not on track. We really need to speed it up or you know what  This pandemic is going to go on for a year longer than it needs to. The problem has arisen due to the lack of vaccinations in low-income countries, while high income countries have far higher vaccination rates. High income countries like the UK are supposed to be donating to poorer states and have pledged a total of  million, but has so far only delivered  million. Coming out of the pandemic is not only vital for peopleaposs general health and well-being, but to the economy and certain sectors that were hit hard when restrictions to work against the spreading of the virus came in. Why might the pandemic continue  One of the reasons why the coronavirus pandemic is still ongoing could be the fact that less economically developed countries with high populations are lagging behind when it comes to the vaccine.Some experts argue that without mass vaccinations across the world, the virus will be able to mutate to the point where the original vaccinations become obsolete, though this is typically dficult to predict.Experts told Massachusetts Institute of Technologyaposs Technology Review : If countries with large populations wait to be vaccinated for years, the virus will keep mutating—potentially to the point that the first available vaccines lose effectiveness. That will be bad for everyone, but poorer countries, with less access to updated vaccines, will again feel more of the impact.United States President Joe Biden said: To beat the pandemic here, we need to beat it everywhere.The aposCovax poolapos was meant to counteract this and make sure that countries who could not afford the vaccines had access to them, through subsidised costs. But some countries, like the UK and Canada have used to pool to get their own vaccines despite having their own contracts with major pharmaceuticals. Under % of the population of Africa has been vaccinated. In the UK  In recent months, many in the UK have deemed the pandemic to be coming to an end. Bars and restaurants have reopened and with vaccinations now widespread, nights out and indulgences in recreational activities have felt like pre-pandemic days. Over  million people in the UK have received at least their first dose of a coronavirus vaccine and  million their second dose. Vaccinations are now available for children over .  But with cases on the rise in the UK , the problem at home has risen to the point where health experts are advising the government reimpose some lockdown restrictions, known as apos Plan B apos. Covid- cases have the potential to overwhelm the NHS and stop patients with other ailments from receiving the care they need.NHS Confederation boss Matthew Taylor, which represents the healthcare systems in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, said: We are right on the edge – and it is the middle of October. It would require an incredible amount of luck for us not to find ourselves in the midst of a profound crisis over the next three months. What is Plan B   Plan B is the governmentaposs contingency plan for winter that would reintroduce some social distancing measures by asking people to work form home, reintroducing masks and working from home, as well as some events requiring vaccine passports. It would be a set back for business recovering from the pandemic, particularly those that were most affected such as hospitality, bars and restaurants and the air travel sector.The government has so far remained resolute in rejecting calls for the measure and business secretary Kwasi Kwarteng said: This time last year we didnapost have the vaccine. We donapost want to go back into lockdown and further restrictions. A spokesperson for Prime Minister Boris Johnson added: As you know it’s something we’re keeping a very close eye on because of the strength of our genomic capability we are able to keep a very close watch on any iants that are emerging.However, during the height of the pandemic, the government became known for U-turns on such policies.
